description:
After dinner, we had time for one more drink. Since Summer Place was on the way, we dropped by on Thursday, October 4th a around 7:15pm.

They have happy hour from 6pm to 8pm. $5.50 for well drinks and drafts. Decided to grab two beers: a Trumer Pils and a Bass Ale. There was one bartender who was nice and attentive. There were only a few customers, so it wasn't too busy. We just sat at the bar for the 30 or so minutes we were here.

Ambiance is definitely divey, but I like that their HH runs until 8pm. Fine for a round or two.
author: Elena N.

description:
On the hunt for real dive bars while visiting SF. Early reckon missions led to disappointment as many of these so called "dives" are  just dressed up to play the part. They lure in the working man and woman with low lights and a long dark bar then charge them 10$ a drink. 

Not Summer Place. They got it right, that is to say they just stumbled upon what they got. Just a classic bar not trying to be anything.

4 dollar High Life's. 25 cent pinball. 1 dollar digital juke box. 

No pool table. No smoking patio. Cash only.
author: Brenton D.

description:
If you love dive bars, come here. Cheap drinks, pinball, low lighting, great place to end the night.
Always meet friends here, never had a bad time.
author: Ryan P.

description: Very rude staff. Friend and I were waiting for another friend and staff was incredibly pushy and overall not a good place to hang out
author: Kevin A.

description: We dropped in on a Thursday night. Clean establishment. Pleasant bartender. A true dive bar vibe, with a digital jukebox that made our night. Excellent place to end your night. Cash Only!!!
author: Danielle T.

description:
Fireplace and a jukebox machine. Need I say more?

My girls and I came on a Saturday night, early enough so that it was just us and maybe two other groups of people. It. Was. Perfect. 

We ordered our drinks, lined up our soundtrack, and staked out near the fireplace. This was a pleasant little find and earned its spot in the "girls night" rotation. ;-)
author: Daniela G.

description:
This is a solid dive bar.  The chairs are on rollers, it's cash only, and everything is around $6-7.  After having been at a super hip cocktail bar, this felt very homey with the fireplace and jukebox.

The drinks were strong (thank you, bartender) and we were able to get seats for a group of 6 easily even though it's pretty small inside.  There weren't a ton of people when we were there, but definitely had groups coming and leaving as we hung out.

I'd recommend coming here at night (obviously, who wants to go to a dive bar in full sunlight).  The fire place and lights from the pinball machines really make this place, and that's something you can only get once the sun goes down.

The jukebox has a minimum charge of $5 and has a good selection.  People were playing music pretty consistently through the night, so make sure to get your songs in the queue!
author: Kenna H.

description:
On a stretch of Bush Street that has several solid, low-key neighborhood bars this is my favorite.

As others have mentioned the owner is very friendly and has been running the place for many years, it's great to talk to her about what's going on in the neighborhood over a couple of drinks.

The music is not too loud and the fireplace makes for a cozy feel.

Love this place!
author: Mike J.

description:
The dude working at 6:15 on Saturday, August 19th was so irritable and rude, it's no wonder we were the only ones there. We came in, he didn't even look up. No "hello." No "welcome in," not even a "what can I get you?" I've never encountered a bartender who was so pissed off to be at work. We got up and left after sitting there for two minutes. 

If I was the owner I would fire him. No question.

No surprise that Hopwater, which is directly across the street, was slammed. Their bartenders are friendly and inviting. 5 stars for Hopwater. If you're looking for a dive, go a couple blocks down to Owl Tree.
author: Tommy H.

description:
Have been visiting SF for the last week, and have ended the day here pretty much every night.

This is the kind of bar I always look for when I am out of town, small, decent beer/drink selection, lots of locals, great prices, and super bartenders.  Either the owner, Sue, and her son Chris have been behind the bar each night, and they are both great bartenders and really friendly.  If you are staying somewhere around Union Square, don't miss this great little dive bar!
author: James D.

description: So my friend and I just came here and sat down waiting for another friend to show up before we ordered drinks. We were here for about 5 minutes. This very aggressive woman then comes up to and starts yelling "Do you think this is a library? You can't just come here and sit down you have to buy something!!" Literally if she had just waited another couple of minutes those purchases would have come flooding in. She demanded to see our IDs, spent way too long examining them because she clearly just wanted a reason to kick us out, and then continued yelling that we had to buy something even though we explained we were just waiting on someone and were minutes away from asking for drinks. We are residents of Nob Hill, don't need a place to bum, and have several other places we can take our business. Honestly how do you expect anyone to want to stay and have a good night at your bar when you've just antagonized your customers? Good luck with that attitude
author: Kesh K.

description: Ice cold beer and great atmosphere. Great location and close to financial district and Chinatown.
author: James W.

description: Wonderful place if you are wanting fun times...good drinks...private conversation but enough back ground nice to enjoy the time while it passes. Clean as well...
author: Gordians K.

description: I don't think I've ever given a 5 star rating to a bar, but this place is perfect to me. Lots and lots of seats, pinball machines, a fireplace, a jukebox you can do on your cellphone AND a full bar for a fair price. Went there twice on a three day weekend. Had a killer Manhatten and icy cold Trumer on tap. Our Austrian guest was even impressed. Conveniently located to the hotels in Nob Hill and the financial district. Just go.
author: Tess S.

description: There's something about this place, the smoke, fireplace, great jukebox. I don't know I have so many good memories there times when I should've had no memory at all. Never have I seen a couple so desperately in need of a room in one of their large comfortable old chairs. Never have I met so many wonderful actors and actresses from some small play house near there. First place I ever bought a round of drinks. I just love it, but it's not for everyone I think that's why I like the most.may your doors never close.
author: Nathan M.

description: This complete rude jerk told four beautiful girls to leave, for absolutely no reason whatsoever! They are rude. The place is super small and very dirty. Don't waste your time traveling to this place
author: Erika L.

description:
Great bar with pin ball game. Cash only.
It has a fire place . Relaxing and cozy . Bartender pours a healthy shot.
Family runs spot. Love here.
author: Xuechen D.

description:
Great dive ish bar with a family owner, cash only. No frills and good drinks. 

Fair prices considering how expensive this town is, hanging out with the owner right now and she's a sweet heart.

It's non smoking and cash only like I said before, there's an atm.

Don't come in here asking for a drink menu, just order a drink and the experienced staff will give you something solid.

Ask the bar tender for a "special".

There's a fireplace and ping pong machines that will entertain your friends.
author: Mike H.

description: 1 star only because there was not  any less rating... The bartender was  on his phone for exactly 8 minutes before he greeted us, after he looked up and saw us.. He then short poured us and I refused the drinks, with ketel 1. He then proceded to argue and pour measured shots of ketel 1 to compare. Not even close!!!! They are flat out short pour scammers, never go!!
author: james r.

description: Dive bar. Cash only. Don't ask for a drink, just tell the bartender how to make it and hope for the best. No music, just an eerie dead quiet and an empty bar. Career alcoholics only need apply.
author: James M.

description:
Stopped by Summer Place Cocktail Lounge during my last visit to San Francisco. Dawn M. and I came across this location while strolling up Bush St. (staying at Hotel Astoria).

Here's what I liked about this bar...

1. The relaxed, comfortable setting. This place is more of a "lounge" than a true "bar". There's plenty of seating at the bar. There are also a number of small tables and chairs.

2. The fireplace! Everyone knows that San Francisco can get quite cold at night. 

3. The low noise level. See #1. Very easy to maintain a conversation while speaking in a normal voice.

4. Friendly service. The bartender noticed us right away and was helpful in suggesting a hoppy beer.

Here's what I didn't care much for...

1. The prices. I guess a lot of bars in SF are overpriced. But 2 drinks for $18? My wallet wasn't too happy with me.

2. Cash only. Again, this seems to be a trend in SF. 

3. Summer Place is small. Luckily, it wasn't too crowded when we arrived. I can see this place filling up quickly.

Will I visit Summer Place on my next SF trip? Maybe.
author: Dan D.

description: Best bar in SF, great people running the place and a solid neighborhood crowd.  My favorite spot in SF.
author: Michael R.

description:
Summer Place: sweet is the place that bears my name!!

I've known about this bar for a while but kept missing my chance to go while I was in the city. I finally made it there and instantly fell in love. I love most dive bars automatically because one can assume they have cheap strong drinks, a dark cozy atmosphere, a casual fun crowd, and a killer jukebox. As soon as I stepped inside the dark bar, dimly lit by christmas lights, I knew all the prerequisities were met. 
But what sets S.P. apart and knocks it out of the park for me is 1) a working fireplace! With fire!, 2) in the half-hour we were there, Queen, Prince and MJ all played on the jukebox (give that DJ a raise! haha), 3) pinball machines including AC/DC pinball, WHAT! and 4) the bar has got my name all over it. Literally. 

Summer Place Cocktail Lounge is officially my favorite dive bar in SF... in the bay area... in the greater northern California region... and, since my beloved hometown dive closed, my favorite dive bar in existence so far.
author: Summer M.

description: if you're in this neighborhood in the evening (i.e. between 6pm and 2am), go to Summer Place!  owner Su is warm and friendly, the drinks are very reasonably priced, and the pinball machines only cost a QUARTER per game!
author: Nancy M.

description:
The worst place i ever was..
1. its very small, dirty and dark
2. NO MUSIC!!! Which bar has no music?
3. My friends (2 Girls) go together to the bathroom. If you are a girl you know thats totaly normal to go sometimes together. It have just one bathroom for Men and Women. But the bar was very small and noboedy else was going to the bathroom so they refresh their make up. Then the Bartender go to the Bathroom door and knockt very loud, and yelled "What are you doing". The bar had no music so everyone was quite and was looking whats going on. He doesnt stop to knock and yell until they open the door. All the people was watching. My friend ask him what is the problem and whats going on. And he just mean they cant go together to the bathroom and what they are doing. She said him how respect less this was and he was getting louder. When she said we are going because this was not okay he just yelled "We should leave". We was all very shocked from how he act, never before someone yelled at me like this. And he really said "Fuck you" to my friend. Such a rude bartender.
author: Randa G.

description: Very divey, the owner is pretty cool and they have some sweet pinball machines. It's a good spot to have a casual beer after work but not a date place at all. I go there with co-workers mostly
author: Mark D.

description: Went in on a Tuesday at around 6:30 and the bartender was not having it. It was during happy hour which was cheaper well drinks. We asked if a tequila sunrise falls into that and the bartender rolled her eyes and said"okayyy" and went on to explain that the more a bartender has to work the more the drink costs in a sassy voice. She did not seem like she wanted to be there at all. Definitely not coming back to this place at this hour.
author: Reeti B.

description:
In my eyes, Summer Place is the coziest, comfiest bar in SF. The drinks are strong and reasonably-priced, the bartenders are all wonderful as it's entirely family-owned and operated, and the atmosphere ranges from raucous and loud to super chill and quiet depending on the time of day and day of week. It's got something for everyone.

They recently spruced the place up and rearranged, adding a few super cool, old-school pinball machines. They have a total of four now, which is remarkable in such a small place. The bar also has an internet jukebox, so you can jam to whatever you want while enjoying a beer or a martini (served with shaker glass and enough for 2 additional pours). 

Summer Place no longer allows smoking inside, which is actually a plus for me. I know it is a drawback if you're a smoker, but it's in a nice neighborhood and there's a great sidewalk outside. Best of all, you never have to worry about the status of your drink while it's waiting for your return atop the bar, because this is a true neighborhood place and even the weirdos aren't creeps. This is one of the few places in the city I can go alone for a drink and not worry about being bothered by other patrons.

Bottom line: I've been to tons of SF divey/neighborhood bars, and Summer Place one is easily my favorite.
author: Meredith S.

description:
Seeing the high reviews for this place, we chose it as the first stop on a bar-crawl night.  Unfortunately, though, it wasn't anything special.  The menu had beer only, so if you wanted a cocktail you would have to just say what you wanted.  Which would have been fine except that the bartender had never heard of a few common cocktails.  When they arrived, the three of us agreed that they were average at best.  And they don't accept credit cards.  

To be fair, though, the bartender was a good guy who was really friendly and did his best, which is why I'm giving three stars instead of two.  The fireplace was also nice.  It wasn't too crowded, but it was a Sunday night when we were there, and it looked small enough that on a Friday or Saturday it might be more of an issue.
author: Michael F.

description:
this is a cool place to grab a few after a long day of whatever. I happened to be staying near by and everything else was closed but I definitely don't regret going here.  The bartender was cool as fuck and the drinks were cheap. I met a couple of cool people there as the place is a decent size yet intimate. 

I'm in town for a couple of weeks but I would definitely go again.

The best way to put it is, a decent place to grab a couple and relax.
author: Caven M.

description: Rolling lounge chairs!  Enough said. You want to sit here and enjoy a few. See you there.
author: Zaki Z.

description: While getting lost in sf Saturday night, we decided to stop by here for our last drink before heading back to the hotel. This place was better than I expected. The Asian lady who runs the place know her taste in music. The place was a little run down but it was just what I expected. There were about 7 ppl in the bar and most of them looked like they have been sitting there fore hours. Drinks where cheap and the bartender was generous.
author: Judy V.

description:
This place is a dive with a fireplace, cheap drinks, christmas lights, a jukebox, and pinball machines including AC/DC.  It is heaven, it is the perfect bar, it is our new flagship drinking hole.  I played some Tom Waits on the internet jukebox and a table of girls gave each other lap dances and I was like, yes, this must be the place.

That's all I know right now because we just discovered it.  I needed to let it be known that Summer Place is LEGIT, and we will be back often.  I think I am about to head back over there right now.  Today is Sunday, so it's still the weekend.

Cash only, party people.
author: Super L.

description: Beer, fireplace, pinball, jukebox, neighborhoody... not bad at all.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Very small chill place that is great if you are trying to catch up with someone or just want a place where there isn't too many people. They also have a pinball machine!
author: Charles Z.

description:
How I'm even able to jot down this review after an epic bar crawl involving nine different watering holes along Bush and Sutter streets is beyond me... like a true degenerate, here I am gloating about my ability to drink in excess with the best of 'em the following morning. 

After a ravishing couple of hours spent between Burritt Room and Chelsea Place (another winner), my ragtag group of friends and I found ourselves at Summer Place. I'm not sure any of us had been there before, so we made like Columbus and discovered the secret wonders of this cozy saloon. And when I say cozy, I mean it! There are deep red accented lights that wrap around the perimeter and look as though they were hung for a Christmas party eons ago, only to never be returned to the dusty cardboard box with "X-Mas" written on top in Sharpie marker ever again. They also have a fireplace against the eastern wall that emits a pretty intense dosage of warm air. Sounds funny that one would geek out on a lit fireplace in the middle of summer, but hey; we live in San Francisco and jackets are a must throughout most of the typical summer months. 

Another notable feature about this bar is that they serve Doritos to anyone who orders a drink! I've seen bars with pretzels, peanuts and Chex Mix before... but I can't say I've ever had complimentary nacho cheese Doritos after ordering a Miller High Life. We also discovered that they make for a surprisingly great chaser after slugging moonshine from plastic bottles that simply say "Whiskey" on the front label.  

The regulars at this place really run the gamut as well. In one corner, there was a young couple engaging in some serious heavy petting (I think we may have witnessed conception in motion), and in another, there was an angry drunk who told me, "here's a flyer: use your fucking mouth and tell people yourself" when I inquired about attaining a leaflet with information on their forthcoming 12 year anniversary party. You really just have to smile and appreciate that sort of candor... it's a lost art!

For the dive bar enthusiast who hasn't yet visited this gem, I highly suggest you make a beeline the next time you're jonesin'.
author: Ruggy J.

description: I'm easilly won over by a place that lets you smoke inside.  I really do like this quaint little hole on the corner.  I've had good Stella and white russians here. Definitely be going back.
author: Sin F.

description:
Although many people call this place a dive, I wouldn't go that far.  The bar is like a leftover from a small town local bar, but it's clean and friendly.  It's just an old school decent bar.  

However, the jukebox here can be addictive.  You can spend lots of money and lots of time picking out songs from your childhood.

On most evenings after work it seems to be mostly empty so it's easy to snag a table.
author: Jean K.

description: I was grabbing a quick beer while waiting for my food from jasmine cafe( which is awesome!!) I didn't have enough cash, so I used the arm machine. No cash or receipt came out. I had already ordered drinks from the bartender with short hair. Sooo rude! I kept telling her that no money came out. She was so rude and said " then leave, no drinks for you." Dont come here, rude bartenders, hipsters, there's a reason why this is always empty.
author: Nick C.

description: In a city w 12 dollar cocktails that buy you a nice ambiance in addition to a good drink, this place is an honest, extremely affordable oasis of comfort. They also have pinball, pacman, and swivel office chairs. I couldn't ask for more.
author: Krucial S.

description:
The perfect local! A small place with everything you need. Full, extremely full bar, fireplace, friendly staff and smoking allowed! The ventilation is good. What more could you ask for?

The bar has a dozen seats. There's plenty of tiny tables too and an awesome jukebox playing classics and chillin' tunes-kudos to the DJ!
author: Dusty S.

description: This bar is perfect for a group of friends looking to have a strong drink! Our bartender was super attentive from the moment we walked in. The bathroom was clean.. right around the corner from The Cellar if you wanna get  your groove on plus if you need a smoke you can step right outside without getting mugged!
author: Iliana S.

description:
My friends and I came here after the 49ers heartbreaking loss to the NY Giants and that kid-of-a-quarterback Eli Manning.
We got wasted. As we should have. The environment here is intimate, dim lit, and, although I hardly smoke, is one of the few bars in town that you can smoke in. Yeah, this place has been around for that long. 
Good selection of music from the jukebox, which fed about $10 that evening. The night was as jolly as a 49ers-lose-their-shot-at-a-Super-Bowl night could be, until the bartender kicked us out.
My friend pulled some dandelions from the bathroom vase and gave them to his girlfriend. I remember she asked him where he got the flowers from. He replied "my heart." 
The bartender later came to the table, yanked our drinks, and told my buddy's girlfriend "you shouldn't hang out with guys who can't afford to buy you flowers!" 
So much for flowers from the heart.
author: Rhys A.

description: I enjoy all of the hip pubs and bars that San Francisco has to offer but Summer place feels like home to me. A great family owned bar full of good people and priced just right for a drinker like me.
author: Buck L.

description:
This is actually my favorite bar in San Francisco, though I rarely make it down here anymore. I've always gotten the impression the bar tender sort of loathes me, but I never mind...that's part of the charm.

Weekend nights these days are a bit busier than I like, but a good week night in this place is perfect. A local joint, casual and friendly, with dim lighting and a roaring fire place, and good music on the juke box. I never come here without meeting someone new and interesting, and I never leave without feeling better about life, circumstances, and the world in general.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
This place gets an extra star for allowing patrons to smoke inside. 

So this bar is called Summer Place but truly, looks like it hasn't seen the light of day in years. A funky fireplace definitely adds a cozy feeling to the place (and hey, isn't a fireplace perfect for a true San Francisco summer night?). There's oodles of seating with tables and rolly chairs ala office strewn about which makes this the perfect nook for drinks and conversation if you are meeting up with a small group of folks. A jukebox in the corner can add to your atmosphere and I have to say, I have yet to run into a jukebox hog. Hooray for adults who know how to take turns! 

The crowd is a grab bag of locals, SF dwellers from other neighborhoods, barflies and tourists. Prices are reasonable for cocktails and a beer won't run you out more than $5-$6. Yes as I happily pointed out, one can imbibe in their smoking habits here. Big ashtrays and decent ventilation make this place an easy, doable compromise for non smoking friends. And the lady who runs this place, while not the friendliest person in the world, is nice enough but she does not play. In other words, shifty people need not cross her threshold because you will not cross her.
author: Veronica G.

description:
Crawl night started at Summer Place. Woooheee nice dive bar! 

Likes - Great spread on the jukebox, classic pinball, nice locals
Dislikes - Smokey

Overall this is a decent bar. A little worn on the edges but still poured some nice drinks for me, Dave, and Tom. It's a solid 3 on the crawl-scale.
author: Nick B.

description: Cool dive bar! The space is on the smaller end but there's a sweet fire place and some games. The bartender/owner was super nice and the drinks are fairly priced. If I lived in the area, this would definitely be a place I'd hang at regularly.
author: Michael N.

description:
Still smokin' strong! Came here for NYE after Bacchus Kirk filled up with hair gel and became as hot as Hades.

Champagne at midnight (yes!) and smoking during the countdown. The fact that you can puff in peace here is a definite plus, for me, at least.

I recommend you have Miller High Life in the bottle, and sit away from the fireplace. It gets hot with that thing in your back all night. Killer juke box, too.
author: Wes T.

description:
This place is cozy, cleaner and a nicer atmosphere than I expected. They have a good range of beers on tap, though I think the beers are overpriced at $5.50 each (where was this happy hour people speak of? We went there directly from work on a Friday).

It's pretty small inside. They have pretzels and goldfish crackers on request. The bartender was a bit indifferent, but nice enough and turned down the jukebox when we requested.
author: Tamara F.

description:
I'll make this one short and sweet: don't go.

My friends and I went there yesterday and I think we brought a little too much "color" to the room; we definitely made the existing patrons uncomfortable as soon as we entered. 

It's definitely divey and they definitely had their regulars. While that's cool, it makes it hard when there isn't anyone else in the bar *except* the five regulars.

Rarely do I get a "this is a creepy place" vibe from a venue (because I happen to love my liquor); but in this case, that vibe was strong enough to have one of us say "do we belong here?" when we walked through the door.

Oh yeah, and they don't accept credit cards. I can't stand cash-only joints. It's sad, because the decor is cool and the drinks were alright. I would still never go back.
author: Kurt C.

description: Awesome neighborhood bar on the edge of the loin. And it's got a fireplace! What more do you really need? Seriously good drinks, and pinball machines complete the vibe. Family run -- not to be missed.
author: James P.

description: I used to have a night class on Thursday nights from 7-9 , so my school best bud Justin and I would meet up beforehand and hit up this spot which was a block or so from our class. It's a magical little dive , great music, weird decor very 70's , and cheap. We would cherish our little ritual here , and then go and somehow get through class. I believe some of my best artistic critiques were aided by my time spent at this funny little spot
author: Lauren V.

description:
When you're nursing a rough crush, a bad breakup, or just need to disappear for a moment, this is where I'd send you.

Sometimes a girl just needs to put 5 bucks in a solid jukebox, belly up to the bar, linger over some whiskey and a cigarette and think about a few things.  This feels like the Montana dive bars I knew and love so well.  I'm glad it's here.

Cash only, but they have an ATM, so get over it.
author: Amanda R.

description: It's cool and divey.  Jukebox, cheap drinks, love the bartender.  I would come back again with great friends and have a good time.
author: Eva H.

description: Been here twice. First time it was pretty packed. Second was pretty empty at 8 on a Friday. Can sear up to 50ppl I'd say. Korean owners. You can but soju here for cheap. Good pregame spot if you want conversation before heading to polk st.
author: Harry M.

description:
Summer Place is a local watering hole just a block or two off of Union Square.  Although it's close to a noisy part of town, the location is somewhat quiet and at the edge of Nob Hill, making it a nice place to go for a drink to.

I think what really stands out is the juke box.  A great selection of songs from 70s rock to modern R&B.  It is a smallish place, so the sound fills the room nicely.  The music can get a little noisy, but it's not as loud as a nightclub!  I've heard from people that they now have a digital jukebox which is slowly becoming the norm, rather than the exception.

Another really neat feature is the large fireplace and you could consider yourself really lucky if you got a seat near the fireplace.  In general, the ambience is good, dive bar-ish, yet small and cozy, warm, low lighting, welcoming and definitely a good place to share a drink or two with friends.  

Nothing out of the ordinary in terms of drinks selection, but cheap drinks are a big plus!
author: Aditya R.

description: Came here to kill some time before going out with friends. It is a chill little bar, pinball machines, jukebox. Bartender was prompt and drinks were good. I'd come back
author: Dany K.

description: What can i say other than it is a dive bar that you can still get away with smoking cigs in.
author: Bomb D.

description:
Summer Place is a bar of contradictions. It's in California, but you can smoke; it's on Nob Hill, but it's somewhat seedy; it's dirty in the bar, but clean in the bathroom. 

There's a good jukebox, a pinball machine, a fireplace, and the drinks are reasonably priced by neighborhood standards. Though it's a small bar, it wasn't too crowded on my two visits to find a seat. The crowd seems to be a mixture of large groups of people who were at other bars earlier, and people by themselves looking to have a smoke, and drink away the memories of the work day. 

Even though I don't smoke I had a good time here. Both times we stopped in, it was with the intention of having "a night cap," but we wound up staying until last call.
author: Michael F.

description:
Red light and jukebox-
ironic S.F. weather!
A fireplace roars...
author: Nathan K.

description:
I love this place--the jukebox, the fireplace, the crowd, and Suzie herself. Perfect for when you want to avoid the crowds and have a drink to figure shit out.

Non-smokers, stop being such pussies already. It's not ever that smoky here and if you really don't like it, go somewhere else. That was easy, wasn't it?
author: Matthew L.

description: The owner may look tough on the outside but she's soft on the inside. It's very cozy and divey. Reminds me of your favorite hometown bar. Beers are $5 each.
author: Hasang Paul K.

description: The only bar I know you can smoke in and it's alright. Love the owner .... She knows my boyfriend and I as the dancing couple who drinks at this bar!!!! Great local bar... Nice fireplace .... Nicer peeps !!!!
author: Brandi R.

description: Good locals-only dive bar. Atmosphere is probably a little dark for the average person, but I like that sort of the ambiance. -1 star for being cash only.
author: Chris H.

description:
I like to be cozy. 
I like to drink. 
I also like to smoke. 

The Summer Place is an amazing little spot that allows me to do all three of those things-- at the same time!

Throw in the fact that it's usually pretty empty in the early evenings(which makes it easy to play "Nightmoves" on the jukebox as many times as I want), and you've got my most favorite dive bar in SF.
author: Heather E.

description:
Dear Smokers,

Dear Lovers of early Zeppelin, specifically, "Babe I'm Gonna Leave You" and/or "Your Time Is Gonna Come,"

Dear Brooders, dear Readers at bars,

Dear Poets and Writers*,

Dear Regulars who want to be regular without being known, or, if known, without being acknowledged, 

Dear Heartbroken fools and the Distraught, 

If it is drizzling out and not too cold, 

If the pavement of Bush Street glistens but does not bounce or puddle, 

If you have sat in Mrs. Ramsay's chair and counted the lighthouse's strokes when she wasn't around, 

If you are capable of staring into a distance, oblivious but self-aware, 

If you appreciate a 50-ish barmaid confiding entirely too much decolletage for her age, 

If you are going, anyway, to listen to Bon Iver through your headphones and walk up and down our fair city's wet hills for hours and hours, why don't you just stop in here for a drink, for a few, because you saw him in some looking-glass perhaps looking after another, because the telephone's been buzzing and buzzing in her empty room, because we have no choice now, because there's no end to this human heart's folly, because we now must seek another, find another, cherish another one....




*Ed. Note: This distinction, so false and so true, always makes your reviewer smile.
author: T U.

description: Everything I want in a bar: well-priced drinks/beers, awesome bartenders, non-pretentious crowd, jukebox, pinball machines, a fireplace..you name it. I learned that it's family-run and that partly explains why this place is amazing (amongst a laundry list of other reasons). The perfect spot to grab a few pints/drinks and be able to enjoy yourself, talk to those you're with, and meet new people. Cheers.
author: Steve B.

description: Perfect little dive bar. I don't smoke but the BF does. It was nice to go somewhere in SF where we could drink and smoke together. Not a lot of outside patios in SF. The 2nd night we went in, the bartender remembered our drinks from the night before.
author: Joanne K.

description:
I am an avid pinball fan and a vehement anti-smoker, which is why Summer Place makes me so happy, yet sad at the same time.  Yes, apparently is is legal for bars operated exclusively by their owners to allow smoking.  This is something you see occasionally in NYC, but I had not seen this before in California.  

It was fairly early on a Thursday and no one was smoking, so lured in by the promise of pinball, we ventured inside.  Grabbed drinks, pretzels, and quarters from the owner, and chatted with her a bit about the reasoning of making it a smoking bar.  I was honestly curious, since a place like this is kind of rare these days.  She seemed very nice, and I was surprised to learn that she was not a smoker herself, although she said she used to be.  I imagine that would be tough!

We played a couple of games, then sat by the faux fireplace for a bit, and then a couple of fellows came in and started to smoke, so we made our exit.  I just wish more non-smoking bars here had pinball!
author: Jaimie M.

description: Liked the place but it reeks of cigerettes and as a former smoker I don't wanna stink. We liked the bartender he was fun. Even liked the pinball but when the 8 people sitting in the bar all lit up at the same time we said see ya later.
author: Bebop M.

description: Leather rolly chairs, juke box, fireplace, smoking, and cheap drinks with zero attitude.  I have truly loved this place for years.  No pretense just a bar.
author: D B.

description: . A bit TOO much of a dive for my taste but it was getting late so we went in. I brought 3 girls with me. (THE ONLY GIRLS IN THE WHOLE PLACE) we ordered a round and waited for the bad music to end but it didn't. Someone put like 6 Bryan Ferry songs in the cue. I tried to put money in the Juke box so it was less annoying but no luck. I then saw the Bartender doing shot after shot with his friends at the bar. I went to buy another beer and he told me cash only. I was out of cash and he said I should use the ATM at the bar. OK....so I'm in a bar that charges $5.50 a beer and now another 2.75 for his ATM machine. then i got to tip $9.25 for a beer in a dive bar with no girls in sight (except the ones with me) I decide against having the beer and the Bartender starts screaming and cursing at me telling me he's the Owner and I have to get the hell out of his bar. I literally thought he was joking but he kept going off (trying to show off for his friends?) what an A-hole.. Had I not been with people from work I would have taught him some manners the old fashioned way. Horrible Horrid place.
author: Brad L.

description: SMOKING? SERIOUSLY? Ew. This was the first bar I ever went to in San Francisco and I was horrified when I walked in and it was smokey. Quickly realized that isn't the norm in SF and left after 1 beer. They did have good music playing and it was a nice little place -- I would have stayed all night and spent a lot at this place if it hadn't been for the smoke. GROSS!
author: Julie W.

description:
Summer Place is a staple. 
A staple like:
White t-shirts
Black purses
White rice
Russet potatoes.

Summer Place is a staple dive with all the bar staples:
A place to sit
Liquor and beers
Dim but atmospheric lighting
A chatty bartendress
Pretzels
A jukebox so tasteful, it's more than a machine.

Too bad I don't smoke, but if you are a smoker this is home for you.
author: Faffy L.

description: This place is nice but the smoking inside I couldn't handle, I quit smoking 3 years ago and I am not going to stay here and get second hand smoke. this place is for smokers not non smokers.
author: barbara v.

description:
Don't support this place. My friend was refused service because he was told they didn't want the "Queen of Sheeba" in their bar. Sure he is friendly and social, but he wasn't inappropriate. I was there when it happened. It put a damper on the evening, and sucked to see discrimination. 


Summer Place. Summer welcome. Summer not.
author: Andy C.

description:
I had one of the best nights of my life in this bar. My boyfriend and I sat next to the jukebox, drinking, smoking, talking, listening to music, and watching the fireplace for hours. 

When we were there, it was quiet, dim, smokey as all hell and filled with small groups of people, chatting quietly and smoking smoking smoking. 

It was cozy and comfortable and damn near the best bar I can imagine. When two girls stood up and started dancing to Al Green, everyone looked up and smiled and went back to their business. They kept swaying together, like no one cared. And they didn't. 

Best fucking bar ever. I would move to SF for this bar.
author: kelly b.

description:
My daddy took my mother here on thier first date...wayyy back in the early 70's. And apperantly they got very very drunk...UH UH!!!
And so I come to this place once in awhile with my boyfriend and we get very very drunk.....I guess it runs in the family.....
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: If you love dive bars, you'll just fall in "like" with this one, as it has a ways to go before it can be classified as a true dive, but it's indeed classically frozen in time! The fireplace and ugly furniture speak of a bad motor lodge lobby circa 1962 ... which is more than okay, because if you wander into any lounge named after a cheesy Sandra Dee film, you've got to expect copious amounts of Velveeta.
author: Gregor G.

description:
If there was a bar that ever personified the Tendernob more perfectly than Summer Place, I haven't found it yet. Emily X dragged me to this place with promises of an amazing bartender named Suzy and some interesting folks. I wasn't let down.

This bar has become a weekly haunt on my mission of becoming a regular. If we see you sitting at our seats at the far end of the bar, you may find yourself evicted from the stools, cunningly, and without prior notice.

Oh, and don't mind the gay Frenchman slurring dirty insults and fondling your ass. You're not special, that's just his way of saying hi.
author: Ben W.

description:
If haphazard mix cd's make your loins quiver, this might be the bar for you.  Insert your dollar into the jukebox and see what kind of hot mess you can spin on that bad boy.  

And if you like drinking in places that look like somebody's parents' weird basement, you will probably like it here.  I know I did.  

If you actually research bars before going to them, this is what you need to know:
--no douche bags (which is a general rule of thumb for dive bars across the land--it's why I love them)
--mixed drinks are $6
--smoking is okay
--fireplace, yes
author: Beth F.

description:
Total dump.  Dark, a little dusty, it hasn't been redecorated in about 30 years, sometimes it smells funny, and there are definitely some interesting, uh, characters that hang out around here.

And that's probably why I like it.
author: Andrew E.

description:
This is such a hole-in-the-wall.  My review is very biased, as I had already had half a bottle of wine and three cocktails before arriving here.  The drinks were good and seemed strong.  The best part, I suppose is that you can smoke here.  Yea.  I was confused, but it was true.  I think the reason we stopped here is because it was right next to my friend's place.  

If you want a dive bar, this seems to be a decent spot.  It consists of your typical dive bar crowd and music, plus it has smoking.  Not my cup of tea, but I'm certain it is for others.
author: Brent A.

description:
I know this guy and he's a douche and insists on lame hole in the wall places to drink,  yeah.
So he demands we go here for cheap drinks and a good jukebox and I'm like are there cool people there?

Well in the end the drinks were strong but jukebox had no Cocteau twins so I was kinda' annoyed at the whole thing. The bartender was cool and nice, she was the best thing about the place
author: Kim S.

description:
While I was visiting San Francisco my friend took me here. 

I was pleasantly surprised! 

LOVE factor- 
smoking inside
fireplace
nice little tables for small groups
red lights
jukebox w/ decent selection
friendly bartender
cheap drinks to get you drank!

I would suggest a better beer selection, and I guess they recently revamped the bathroom...which is now very big/spacious/sterile. It doesn't really mesh with the vibe, but a clean bathroom is a good one! 
Also, my friend walked in on a guy air-guitaring in front of the toilet..hahah!
author: jane l.

description:
I can sum it up in one word: Eh.

Sweet old rotating-leather lounge chairs give the impression that Summer Place could have been a retro joint in the style of classic '60s/'70s TV detective-show reruns --- but someone did a minimal fixer-upper job and now Summer Place feels lost. Located halfway between the Tenderloin and Union Square, it could either be a divey boozepit or a crisp cocktail boite. Right now, however, it's neither.

Very little decor to speak of. Unexceptional jukebox. OK prices. If you're looking for class and flash, take a right upon exiting. If you're looking sass and trash, take a left. (I went left.) In either case, I don't foresee myself returning until Summer Place makes up its mind what it really wants to be.
author: John G.

description: After not finding seats at the more trendy/ popular bars on Powell, we found this place just off Powell on Bush.  A number of observations: 1) you can smoke inside this bar  A very nostalgic experience. 2) about 5 - 7 beers on tap including Fat Tire.  3) was not too crowded and/or loud where one could not carry on a conversation.  4) it's a dive bar so if that is what you are looking for: the summer place fits the bill nicely.
author: ira b.

description: Awesome place to have a drink with no pomp and circumstance.  The owner is great and the crowd is laid back. Come in and have a drink.
author: RJ V.

description:
The furnishings are random.
The fireplace is just odd.
The service is indifferent, yet humorous and tongue-in-cheek.
The drinks are small, but strong.
It's dark. 
The crowd is mixed.
Everybody's there for one reason: to drink with friends.

My kinda dive.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
When you're at a dive bar  - Benders (http://www.yelp.com/biz/benders-bar-and-grill-san-francisco#hrid:iRXx3tzAiCeZCsDto1S1mg)  - and someone gives you a recommendation for another dive bar, you go. That's how I ended up at Summer Place. 

Summer Place's lack of a "scene", lack of Mission Hipsters, decent drink prices and permissible smoking have made it a now "go-to" spot in my book. I probably would'a gone 5 stars if it wasn't for the fact that the guy behind the bar didn't know how to make a 7&7. There is no excuse for not knowing what a 7&7 is... especially at a dive bar.
author: Natasha R.

description:
Summer Place has personality crisis written all over it. Small room, fake wood paneling, Naugahyde swivel chairs, cigarettes and ashtrays. And a Korean momma behind the bar! In a dive like this you'd expect to find down-and-outers but instead you get out-of-towners (and the odd NOPA exile).

Don't expect anything fancy from this joint. I tried to order a Butterscotch shot, which was one of four advertised drink specials. The bartender shrugged: "What's Butterscotch?" I settled for a Bud Light.

Due to its location Summer Place gets a fair share of travelers and Nob Hill refugees. Last night, one of said Nob Hillers owned the place. A pretty young thing with flowing raven hair. Wearing a black dress that left nothing to the imagination. All over a rich dude's lap. Summer Place, meet Summer Love.
author: William L.

description: My friend as my friend and I were  looking for some non- touristy bars in SFO I came across some reviews for this place on Yelp.  Thanks to the people that gave it one star for being a smoking bar, I was on my way!  Being from Vegas, I'm used to smoking in bars and was super stoked to find this one (in fact, it's the only one I know of in CA).  The bartender/owner, Suzy, was super nice and accommodating and made great drinks.  Definitely a bar I will return to on my next trip to SFO!
author: Katie V.

description:
Prince, Madonna, Donna Summer, David Bowie and I all get together on Friday nights at the Summer Place.  We dance and sing in front of the warm fireplace.  We consume the $5 beers, $5 no matter which beer you get.  And then I drunken stumble the two blocks to my apartment alone.  

But one of these nights I am going to take my little red wagon into the Summer Place and load that amazingly stupendously fucking awesome jukebox onto the wagon and take it home with me. Then Price, Madonna, Donna Summer, David Bowie and I will get together and dance in my living room where the beers are only $2, $2 no matter which beer you get.
author: Alexis M.

description:
how have i never known of this place?!  especially back when I was a smoker's smoker!?  I wandered in here last night and it was as if I walked into a movie.  a movie from the 60's/70's.  Everyone turned to look at you with suspicion when you walked in.  I think someone said Nixon era and another said Elks Lodge.  It's true.  It's dark.  It's got round tables with those cushy chairs with arms.  It's got a fireplace.   It's got ole blue eyes on the jukebox.  It's all true.  Unfortunately the drinks weren't cheap, but they were tolerable ($5 for a pint).

This is the best place to come if you want to pretend that you're being pursued and need a dark joint to lay low in for awhile (or you really are and do....).  Think film noir.  That's it!  This place should be in black and white.   And there should be a secret code word to get in.
author: Kerry L.

description:
Really love this place: one of the most comfortable neighborhood bars around, great jukebox, and a pretty nice bartender. It's the kind of place I'd invite friends to, to talk about the day's events, laugh and get tipsy. The jukebox selection is pretty good, and somehow I always get lucky with what others are playing here!  It's also quite low key, got a good fireplace and is really great if you don't have the energy to be in a crowded, noisy bar.

The drinks selection is the usual stuff, nothing too fancy. Not too expensive either. Definite pluses are the fact that you can get your own food inside: no fuss. And you can smoke indoors too.....my smoking friends appreciate that. 

All in all, my kind of place!
author: DJ R.

description:
I hate to be negative, as I'm all for neighborhood bars, including the Summer Place. But this place sucks! Not because its drinks are weak or the atmosphere is lame. 

No, it sucks because the owners of the Summer Place haven't put a sign up outside their entrance asking smokers or people standing in front of the entrance to keep their noise down as people may be sleeping.  I understand it's a bar and some noise is to be expected. But when Nob Hill neighbors have to keep calling the cops to  disperse the crowds it's just ridiculous.

So if you're at the Summer Place, and you have to step outside to smoke, hail a cab, or just chat with your mates, remember there are people who live within earshot of any loud noise that one might create.
author: David G.

description:
I was going to give it 3 stars because as far as I'm concerned, nothing really stands out about the Summer Place aside from the fact that you can smoke (which isn't really a selling point for me).

But then I realized that's why it's great: it's just a place where you can drink, sit down with someone and talk.  In other words, what a bar should be.  None of this bar/lounge/club bullshit, you come here to hang out and drink reasonably-priced booze.

Go dive bars!
author: Joseph N.

description:
Good news, guys: Summer Place isn't anywhere near (if at all) as tacky or dingy as it looks from the outside. 

A merry crowd, a live fire, dim lighting, intimate tables, spinning cushioned wheely chairs, and cigarette-smoking. What else could you ask for on a Saturday night?

When we went, there was apparently a Japanese-American high school reunion that had taken over a majority of the tables... But we still found seating and plan on going back earlier next time to hog the jukebox.

Warning: Cash only!
author: G. J.

description:
The whole dark '70s vibe of the place (and my usual state of inebriation) makes me feel like I'm the Harvey Keitel character during the "Rubber Biscuit" bar/party scene in "Mean Streets." Good thing I don't have to deal with Johnny Boy.

I could totally imagine this place (or one like it) packed to the gills in the '70s. Give it a few ferns and it's virtually identical to the singles bar where Goldie Hawn meets Dudley Moore in "Foul Play" (yes, I know, another film reference).

Nowadays, it doesn't get too crowded, which is a plus. It's always easy to get a table and some chairs...which makes for a nice place to smoke some cigs, soak up some booze, groove to the awesome '70s jukebox, and chat with some fellow drinkers.
author: Derek R.

description: The Summer Place in my opinion is the greatest dive in San Francisco.  I have come here twice now, once last year when I was in town and again just last week.  The seats are cozy, it's nice and dark, the regulars and other patrons are friendly, the new digital jukebox is full of great classics and the drinks on tap are cheap and tasty.  The woman behind the bar is sassy, funny, and she loves Patsy Cline and Bill Withers which is my kind of person! My fiancee and I will always make a point to set aside a night where we can drink away our sorrows when we are in town at this bar.
author: kate m.

description:
Definitely not a bad place to chill with friends and have a few adult beverages and share adult jokes, becuse hey, we're all adults here right?   It has a little fireplace (weird for a 'sumemr place'), limited seating, and the decor hasn't been updated since the Nixon Administration, not that that's a bad thing.  
The jukebox, is the best part, (although barely audible when crowded) it has Too Short's "Get In Where you Fit In" album, which I basically listened 5000 times freshman year of college.  How could you ever get tired of BJ Betty?  That's all i wanted to say about this place, that, and the fact that you could possibly address your nicotine fix here... indoors, and i don't mean chew, not that i told you this.  it's just a rumor....
author: Pej A.

description:
the smoke...the juke boxe...the atmosphere...the owner 's big boobs...
the fire place... 
feels just like summer!
a place where it never feels like winter!
author: verstonku a.

description:
What a Dive!  It's a locals local if you know what I mean. 
Great for a late night drink or two . . .
author: Mary N.

description: Very mellow vibe here which I totally love.  The jukebox kicks ass and the drinks aren't overly expensive.  I'd imagine this place would suck when it gets crowded but when it's nice it could be a cool place to chill with a couple of good friends.  Don't let the name fool you, the Summer Place is totally hot.
author: Amy J.

description: This is a welcoming, friendly and comfy place to meet your friends ,have a drink, catch up on events and just hang out.  Kris  the bartender makes divine Margaritas and the place is cozy without being noisy ...the perfect spot relax, wind down and  finish off your evening
author: Lynn Ruth M.

description:
Nice little dive bar, with these cool twirly chairs that you can rock the tunes with. Some peeps n me had a lot of great tunes going in the jukebox and decided that twirly chair dancing was the next BIG thing. 

It's the stop after a trip to The Tonga Room, where your wallet's been ravaged by weak drinks.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Was brought here by a friend for a drink (or two or three or ten) - Susie rocks and so do the jukebox selections, warm fire, and neighborhood feel...plus you can smoke inside - hard to find in San Francisco:)...stumbled home after a fantastic experience there:)
author: Brooke C.

description: Nice chill atmosphere, relatively cheap beer.
author: Jorge H.

description: My friends and I come here a lot.  I can't say it's my favorite bar in the city, or even in the area, but it feels like home in a dark, alcoholic sort of way.  The drinks are pretty cheap and the bartender (Susie) rocks- there's a good jukebox, a fireplace, and you can smoke inside (my least favorite thing about the place- but if you are a smoker, I guess that's a big selling point).  Cash only.
author: Tovah S.

description:
Actually, this place is probably only 3-stars worthy -- there's nothing exceptional that makes it stand out from all the other places -- but it's right outside my door and that earns it the fourth star.

The servers *are* nice, though, and there's that jukebox, so I guess those count for something.
author: Chris M.

description:
The summer place is one of those places that just is so much fun!! It is simple and nothing special which is what is so great about it!! Sue is the best and totally does not put up with shit!!
Love to sit there on a cold night and watch the fireplace!! 
Love the holiday fun that Sue puts on!! mmm love the food!!
author: Danny B.

description:
I love this place. It's nice to drink here on a weeknight, because there are usually only four or five other people in the bar. I came here with one of my friends; he and I were hoping for just the two of us to talk and hang out, but that didn't happen. Despite the change of plans, we both had an awesome night. If you want an intimate conversation, sit by the fireplace at one of the tables, although this way you can't talk to the bartender, who is awesome.
Pretty cheap, good Jack&Cokes and Gin&Tonics, awesome jukebox. Love it.
author: Jordan S.

description:
My liver hurts just thinking about this place!  This is such a chill neighborhood bar.  It kind of reminds me of a basement in the 'burbs circa 1979.  The great music (Purple One, we salute you!), strong beverages, smoking allowed, and comfy chairs keep me coming back.  Plus the bartender keeps the pretzels flowing and looks out for her female customers.  She's not afraid to lay down the law and kick out creepers that get out of line.

My only question is, why do they keep Red Bull in crazy mason jars behind the counter?  Anyone?
author: Bonnie G.

description: I was there NYE like 2 years ago. Not only was the bar owners awesome, they had full spread of sandwiches, cocktail weiners! And they broke out the New Year noisemakers. Great hosts, and did I mention you can smoke inside!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Chez R.

description: I love Susie and I love this place. I don't smoke, but I pretend I'm in Vegas when I'm here and breathe shallowly  (where can you go and have a beer in Vegas without smoke)?
author: Timothy C.

description: I wasn't alive in the 70's, but for some reason when I imagine a typical neighborhood bar in the 70's, this would be it. It's also the quietest bar I've ever been to. We went there on a Friday night, and there were only 2 people in there. It was so quiet that I could actually have a conversation with my friends. Then someone turned on the jukebox and played Billy Joel. It was really chill. It's kind of dark and there's a fireplace in the corner. I would frequent this place all the time if I lived closer.
author: Jade S.

description: Yay! Another bar in town with a loungy feel and a fireplace. They have tables and chairs reminiscent of the Owl Tree or The Page but with a whole lot more room. Average drink prices and a mixed crowd. This would be a good place to take a date, that likes lowbrow places, for a makeout session at the end of the night.
author: Drue C.

description: I always make sure to stop by this place when I'm in SF to start off the night. Very chill, good jukebox, and good prices.
author: Lloyd B.

description:
a drinking buddy and i came here last week, once we heard you can smoke inside. there were only some older men there, one guy was  talking about some weird shit, i dont remember exactly but i recall thinking "hmm... i dont know if id say that out loud around strangers" and he didnt seem drunk at all. 

then this one cat put like 10 bucks in the jukebox and played damn near every beegees song. (1 dollar gets you three plays, i swear he mustve put 7 or 8 bucks in there)

every other album on the juke was pretty damn awesome, i put in a dollar and played tom waits and tribe called quest.... and i forget what song my friend played. but it was a good one.

 my friend was complaining that there werent any females there, much less the only other cat our age was the bartender. i didnt really care, there are plenty of times i want to just kick it at some dark bar, listen to good music, and be left to my own ( im not saying, 'leave me the hell alone,' its just theres more than one occasion where small talk isnt entirely necesary and im not trying to hook up with anyone)

drinks are reasonably priced. good music, dark, indoor smoking. itll be a spot i stop at maybe often but not daily, nor where i go on a friday night. other than the creeper and the goddamn beegees, a legit spot.

oh! last thing, i actually thought this was pretty hilarious:
one guy answered his phone- "hi honey... yeah, im at Summer's Place... Summer's Place.... What?? No! SUMMER'S PLACE, you know, in union square? yeah. yeah. that place."
so guys... if you're here and your girl calls, i would just tell her youre at a dive bar, it'll probably save you a fight
author: Richard L.

description: I love this place! Suzie the bartender is hilarious.
author: Michael G.

description: I went to this place on an out of town visit from L.A.  It's so cool - no idiots hitting on us, saying stupid stuff and interfering with our good time. From the barrel shaped chairs, the fireplace, the JUKEBOX  (awesome) to the friendly bartender, this was the coziest little dive bar I could've hoped for. People were smoking their asses off, however, so if you can't deal with that, then maybe you shouldn't come.  Anyways, we sat there all night - no need to travel elsewhere.
author: Teri F.

description: Ah, yes, Summer Place. Feels like a Korean Elks Lodge. Suzie always takes care of you, keeps the Fernet chilled, and don't take no shit. Owner operated, so you can smoke, and there is always someone there worse off than you. A nice quality in a dive bar.
author: Big S.

description: Good service, reasonably priced drinks, smoking inside and a fantastic juke  box selection. All together a pleasant experience.
author: Anne A.

description: pretty effin awesome when you can go to a downtown bar on a friday night and there are only 5 other people in there! Good juke box..went there for a 1st date the other night and it was perfect!
author: Inome C.

description: I don't know why it's called Summer Place. Maybe it's because of the sunflowers in the vase behind the bar. It doesn't matter, really, because this place is delightful. The bar isn't too big or too small. There's a cozy area next to a gas fireplace. The jukebox has a good selection. The owner, Susie, is very nice and constantly refreshes your pretzels and ashtrays. That's right, this is a smoking bar. It's legal. The place seems well ventilated, however, and the smoke doesn't get too thick for comfort. Comfortable, inexpensive and neighborhoody. Go there and enjoy.
author: Zibdabity B.

description: I was here for 5 minutes. It was strange, weird, desolate, thought I stepped into Reno. We left. Too scary for me.
author: Mama C.

description:
dark, smelly, and strange.

this is my kind of place. not that i am any of those things, at least i don't think so... wait. whatever. anyways, everyone is there for a reason: to drink. 

and drink, we do. over and over again until we can barely walk back up the hill. the owner is great and it is usually really low-key on weeknights. funny music selection and yummy beers.

i dig.
author: Syd V.

description: I stumbled upon this place trying to go to the owl bar which always seems to be closed anymore.  Once again it was closed so my friends and I walked a block or so and found this place.  We walked in to immediately notice people smoking, which was weird.    This place is pretty low key and has an awesome juke box.  Love it.
author: Patti S.

description: your total dive bar near union square. we finished dinner and decided to get a drink somewhere. walked around and this was the first place we came across. i don't like this place because you're allowed to smoke inside however its probably a smoker's heaven b/c you can! they have a juke box where you can play music if you pay. they have one bathroom for both men and women. the drinks are super cheap but depending on what you want they might not have that much selection. and they are also CASH ONLY!
author: Jen S.

description: What a great little hole of a bar and I mean that in the best possible way.   From the fireplace to the jukebox to the mesmerizing Miller Genuine  Draft sign behing the bar, it rocks. If you happen to be on Bush & Taylor and you need a drink or even a dark place to lay low you could certainly do a lot worse than the Summer Place.
author: matt l.

description: I gave this place such a high rating because its a nice escape from the "wannabe swanky" spots in the area!  Its super chill, the drinks are great and cheap, and the people are refreshing and down to earth.  Where else can you go with a fireplace, kewl jukebox tunes, and cozy corners?  I will be hitting up this place late night whenever I'm in the area!
author: MaRitZa G.

description: I love this place.  The juke box is full of all my favorite music circa 1996 and the pretzels are bottomless, there is no better place to spend a Wednesday night.
author: Greg M.

description: Count me as a fan, Summer Place.  Your rocky facade, your smoking policy, your cold beers tapped by a sweet old lady, your jukebox full of seventies gems (Stevie, Steely, etc.), and your fireplace have all earned you a spot in my top dives to hit after work.
author: sunny d.

description: The bartender here is a dime. Best juke box in town and she takes recommendations. I was REintroduced to Curtis Mayfield here. I can order pizza and have it delivered while i wait for it w/my friends and have a drink. Its mos def a place where everyone knows your name.
author: C. G.

description: This place is the definition of a neighborhood dive.  Weirdly enough the neighborhood is nob hill so I don't make it up here very much.  Almost every time I bar hop downtown or nob hill I try to end the night here, and I especially enjoy showing my find off to people who have never been.  Last year before thanksgiving I went here and they had made a thanksgiving meal and were giving it away for free!  Between the ambiance, family feel, and relaxed attitude ; )  this is one bar I wish I made it to more often.
author: Nate W.

description: Dark place (and not in that sexy lounge type of way).  Good jukebox, decent drink prices, and a lax policy regarding smoking indoors.
author: Tamar N.

description: Solid dive bar in Nob Hill area of all places.  Scene is dark and dingy, intimate w/ a fireplace.  As noted, great juke box.  All around great bar to have some mellow cocktails w/ friends.
author: John R.

description: Where have you been hiding at Summer Place? You are just the right escape I need when I come back downtown and need to chill out with a drink and a friend. It meets all my requirements: good beer on tap, dark, seats, and a jukebox. Yeah, the jukebox is kinda bad, but  a good bad. After a couple of drinks you'll be singing right along to Ambrosia or Tony Braxton but who cares? You're having a good time where it ain't super scenestery and the owner is great and treated me and my lady friends like family. She is witty, can take a joke and lets you smoke inside and shares the snacks. I will be back again and again!!
author: Gina c.

description: I live right around the corner from this place and was always skeptical until I went in a couple of years ago.  Since then I have been HOOKED!  Suzy is FIERCE!  I take people and out of town friends here all the time and they fall in love.  Gotta be the best Jukebox in the city...and a fire place????  Whaaaaa?  Drinks are cheap and if you are a smoker you dont have to stand outside.  Suzy is the only one who works there, therefore the bar has a smoking permit...the best dive bar with a little class...LOVE IT!
author: Patrique R.

description:
This is a cozy neighborhood bar with a fireplace and the best jukebox I've ever come across. It's also one of the few places in the city you can smoke in since it is 100% owner operated and therefore smoking ban exempt. 

The owner, Suzy, is awesome and will take good care of you so long as you respect her place. This is my favorite place to come and unwind with a cold beer and some conversation after work, or for some serious drinking on the weekends.

As for the others on here that are accusing this place of doing something illegitimate, I implore you to call the police and then proceed to stick your foot in your mouth as they laugh at you. I see nothing about your story that justifies your claims against the Summer Place. 

"OMG she kicked us out! They must be doing something illegal!"

 Wait, what? 

Yea, you got kicked out. It happens, but whats with this personal crusade against this little Asian lady's bar? Are you so important that this family owned business should be shut down for refusing you service? If you don't like the place, there are hundreds of other bars in the city. Grow up, kids.
author: Matt G.

description: This one of my favorite dives in lower nob. This place has a great jukebox, a little gas fireplace and the lighting of an opium den. Summer Place is great for a group of people with little cocktail tables and those low chairs with wheels. Drinks are fairly priced and they'll let you bring in your own food.
author: mike m.

description: This is a great place to go if you just want to be left in peace and catch up with friends over some drinks.  It's relatively quiet after work and for the most part you don't have to worry about getting a table or being able to hear yourself talk.  The bartenders are awesome, and I love the permarock facade and  the "original" 1960's decor.
author: cecilia g.

description:
I can't lie.  I'm physically incapable of it.  So when I say that I can usually stop myself from drinking too much, I actually mean it.  For some reason, and I really can't explain it, Summer Place MAKES ME DRINK.  I mean, I can actively know that i'm shitfaced, I can actively know that I've smoked a pack and want more, and I can actively know that I have to be up for work the next morning...but I can't stop.  No other bar makes me want to drink as much as I can as quickly as I can.
To test my theory I took fairy-Matty after a ball game at ATT Park.  Had been on Angel Island all day drinking wine, at the ball game drinking beer, hadn't eaten all day....and sigh...was at Summer Place for 5 hours pounding beer.  
Something about the fire place, the leather swivel chairs, and the lady who's name I can never remember but who has a really high voice and is UBER-nice....makes me want to drink A LOT.
author: Zev K.

description:
Yeah I guess it was a Sunday evening but still this bar was way quiet.  Just two older gents and the dirty mouthed bartender lady in there at first.  I got a beer and sat down by the fire place.  the chairs look like bucket seats with rollers on the bottom.  It seems like a place where people should be playing cards.  The atmosphere would probably be helped by smoking.  Heh.

Other people came in and then one of the two older gents walked out as soon as the music started playing.  Scared away by the rock 'n roll.    I like the ambiance.  Really cozy.  Seems like only 40 people could fit in there comfortably.
author: Daniel K.

description: It's simply a cool bar to enjoy during the night. I dont smoke but dont mind others do...smoking is only allowed in bars as long as the owner is the only one-employee serving in the establishment.
author: Tony A.

description: Skip the pretentious bar scene at the Clift and head over to Summer Place at 801 Bush and Mason. This is one dive bar you could only find in SF.
author: Ammo Marketing ..

description: When I walk in the door and am greeted by Suzy, a warm fireplace in the dark, and a jukebox that includes such favorites as "Easy Lover", "Do you Realize", and "Moonshadow"....I know I can settle in and enjoy the night.  Recently, the smoking has been restricted to the front section of the bar due to complaints of a new tenant upstairs, but you still can get cheap drinks, free food on holidays, and a nice place to sit back in your wheeled leather chair with good buddies for a nice long chat.
author: susie t.

description: For those newly situated in the lower Nob, look no further for your local.  The rock-clad wall, mock tudor beams, low-light and fireplace provide a cozy backdrop to enjoy Su -the owner/bartender's- great drinks and spirited service. Maybe you'll even get a chance to feed the jukebox a dollar and cue up some Roy Ayers, Bill Withers, or Shuggie Ottis.  The lack of a comparable in my new Hayes Valley hood has me frequently returning to A Summer Place.
author: Aaron V.

description: i just found this dark little bar last night, and i like it. you may not find the hottest looking crowd here, but its a great if you're trying to get away from the "scene". this is where you come to have a serious drink.(gin straight up, no rocks) its not too loud, no one looks at each other and the only light comes from the fireplace. this might be a dive, but it comes with genuine personality and charm. i know a large majority of my girlfriends will refuse to frequent a place like this with me, but i know a few of my guy friends will like it. very nice chill spot.
author: Michelle I.

description: I used to hate going to bars.  I love going to the Summer Place.  The bartenders are very nice (as long as you're nice to them), and you can smoke inside.  Drinks aren't any pricier than any other bar in the neighborhood, and the regulars that go there are pretty entertaining as well.
author: Cameron J.

description:
this used to be a staple for me, as i used to live across the street.  i love Suzy.  she is the bartender wednesday thru sunday and she rocks.  i had thanksgiving there last year.  i took my gf there on one of our first dates we sat by the fire place and looked in to each other's eyes with wanton abandon.  countless drunken nights there and Suzy always forgave me the next day.  i have a lot of great memories here.  
in fact i really like this bar and it might qualify as one of my city favs.  
it is definitely a quality dive.  it has a home like feel/quality.  Suzy always treated me exceptionally well.  i can't say enough good things about this place.  the best.
author: Anthony Y.

description: this was one of my old haunts when i lived in the area.  at the time i was a smoker, so i loved that you could smoke inside.  also, the jukebox was really eclectic- i remember bauhaus, mariah carey, and guns n'roses all on the same jukebox.  there is a fireplace and these weird chairs that are really comfy.  the bartenders were always friendly and the drinks were cheap and strong.  i used to go here after work, it's usually pretty mellow then.
author: Kate W.

description: just discovered this little gem with my friend, summer. strolled in because of the name. low lighting, fireplace and you can smoke inside. the jukebox rocks your socks off. what more could one ask for? not crowded for a saturday night either. drinks are a bit pricey but its downtown so its expected.
author: Scott L.

description: haven't hit this place yet on a weekend, but during the week it's the bee's knees.  hard to describe the vibe, but a conglomeration of L.A. passe and Milwaukee grime might come close.  if that doesn't appeal to you, it should.
author: Nathan G.
